snippet.textDisplay: Tbh I like HFCEV cars more than BEV cause they make more sense... and will create cheaper infrastructures than the big waste of money battery stuff will be. They say we're working on 'better battery technology' well, HFC is the better battery technology, just not in the traditional sense of the battery. It's basically a battery that works in different ways that you don't charge with electricity but with Hydrogen and it produces electricity. The whole definition of 'battery' is a container that contains chemicals that will produce electricity.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm gonna keep driving a petrol + LPG(Autogas) cars. It has all the fun stuff of a normal petrol car (it IS a petrol car, only modified to use LPG as well) but you drive mainly on the LPG which costs half as much as petrol, and my car normally uses 7,5 litres of petrol for every 100km (a little bit more than 60 mil), and when I drive on LPG it consumes slightly more than that, 8-8,5 litres of LPG.
On one tank of LPG I can drive 400km (250 miles).It produces by 96% less nitrogen oxides compared to diesel, 68%
compared to petrol, and 120 times less particulate matter than diesel.
You don't loose any performance (early LPG systems did that -> you were loosing power), nowadays ones like STAG, BRC, KME, Prins, Lovato don't do that. You still have your normal car, but pay 50% for the fuel and make a lot less mess to the environment.
Costs of modifying your petrol car usually are less than 600EUR (at least where I live, Poland).
You can modify diesel engine as well, but it won't pay back as quickly.
Mine paid back itself after 15.000KM (9,320miles) - so less than a year of driving for me.
You can buy brand new car with LPG preinstalled (for example some Fiats, Opels, Dacias or Toyotas etc.).

Why don't use it? Why didn't any of the TRIO talked about it? Like - never even mentioned it?

snippet.textDisplay:
I have to say, I'd really like to discuss issues like that with James in a pub or so.

Well since that is unlikely to happen I'd like to use this comment section to add at least two things:
- 1st: I'm really disappointed that pro hydrogen James didn't mention how when Richard Hammond crashed a BEV it kept spontaneously bursting into flames for days
- 2nd: Pro BEV James really shot himself in the foot with the efficiency argument. You can't complain about efficiency and just minutes later propose large scale inductive charging which is laughably inefficient!
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Just a clarification: at 7:50 James says that a "slight risk on a (cold) day like this is that the nozzle freezes to the car". This is not correct: hydrogen has a negative Joule-Thomson coefficient, so it actually heats up when expands, just the contrary of what happens to GPL or methane.
snippet.textOriginal: Just a clarification: at 7:50 James says that a "slight risk on a (cold) day like this is that the nozzle freezes to the car". This is not correct: hydrogen has a negative Joule-Thomson coefficient, so it actually heats up when expands, just the contrary of what happens to GPL or methane.

snippet.textDisplay: ELECTRiC IS NOT THE FUTURE
snippet.textOriginal: ELECTRiC IS NOT THE FUTURE

snippet.textDisplay:
A correction (to what is a brilliant video!)

Hydrogen can't be dropped into existing fueling stations because it needs to be stored at pressure and it leaks like a sieve. New infrastructure will be required and it is EXPENSIVE. About $1 MILLION a PUMP currently. Not a station, A PUMP. The chance of an infrastructure being built out to support millions of hydrogen cars is a flat-out fairy story. It won't happen.

While the technology is a fun science project, the notion that we can all drive hydrogen cars is a nonsense - a nonsense generally peddled by oil companies who say "don't go electric now, wait until hydrogen cars come in 10 years!" ,... Which they've been saying for 40 years. All the while, you're buying petrol. Which is how the scam works.

Don't believe the scam. The future is NOT hydrogen, the future is BEV.

snippet.textDisplay:
I’m still more a fan of hydrogen power. However, yes I am aware the emissions from it are not actually just clean water everyone says. It could use getting cleaned up a bit but i my uneducated opinion is a more convenient option then batteries.

My little science book on electricity when I was young used to say that in 2020 (I’m old okay...) cars would pull into filling stations and swap batteries for new charged ones... that’s a better idea to me. But still a bad one logistically because it requires people to return to the same station for batteries or eventually all the batteries will end up in one station.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Tesla is not an environmentally friendly future, and Elon Musk doesn't care about saving the planet. Making disposable tech toys made out of materials that are highly polluting to produce and extract, which amount to an individual vehicle that will probably be changed every few years, instead of investing in things like public transportation (trains, buses, etc) is not being ecologically minded. Let's not let the industry lure us into thinking that buying disposable electric cars is the answer to climate change.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hydrogen fuel cell vehicle well to wheels energy efficiency is 3x to 4x worse than Battery Electric Vehicles. That makes them on par with fossil fuel vehicle energy efficiency, which is poor.

Most commercially available Hydrogen is made from Natural Gas (Methane), a fossil fuel. That's why FCVs are supported by the oil industry over EVs.

The fossil fuel based Hydrogen gets to most filling stations via Diesel powered tanker truck.

For most drivers, the time to charge an EV is totally irrelevant. They plug in at home or work and the car is full long before they need to leave. And almost no one drives down to empty.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hydrogen fuel cell vehicle well to wheels energy efficiency is 3x to 4x worse than Battery Electric Vehicles.  That makes them on par with fossil fuel vehicle energy efficiency, which is poor.  

Most commercially available Hydrogen is made from Natural Gas (Methane), a fossil fuel.  That's why FCVs are supported by the oil industry over EVs. 

The fossil fuel based Hydrogen gets to most filling stations via Diesel powered tanker truck.

For most drivers, the time to charge an EV is totally irrelevant.  They plug in at home or work and the car is full long before they need to leave.  And almost no one drives down to empty.

snippet.textDisplay: That was a slow charge on the SuperCharger. My Model 3 starts out charging at 600 mph when low (< 40%). Most of the time it gets 200 miles in about 35 minutes, but I can get a quick 50 miles in 5 minutes. The other nice thing is the SCs are all over the Interstate system and in cities around the U.S.
snippet.textOriginal: That *was* a slow charge on the SuperCharger.  My Model 3 starts out charging at 600 mph when low (< 40%).  Most of the time it gets 200 miles in about 35 minutes, but I can get a quick 50 miles in 5 minutes.  The other nice thing is the SCs are all over the Interstate system and in cities around the U.S.

snippet.textDisplay:
It’s going to be an interesting battle between the technologies. When you have a company the size of and with the ‘clout ‘ of Toyota, investing an awful lot of money in the fuel cell, well it has to be a runner. They are developing full BEV’s at the same time though, first one believed to be available in “less than 3 years.”
Either way, it’s exciting times for the motor industry.

snippet.textDisplay: Tho I guess if you live in a northern land, like Russia or Canada, if it gets under -25C or lower, the Tesla can have issues, I know electric cars will have issues in Canada cause I live there and -30C or lower is common in most of my land. Tho I would like to know about the hydrogen one in a country that as pretty much 8 months of winter a year? Cause the electric car don't really cut it, even diesel is not good unless pluged, the gas or petrol car is pretty much king here, well unless the hydrogen one can start in lower colds then -30C, I don't see the electric car yet a thing here, unless they build plugs everywere a car can be parked? Oh and just to add, tho were I am living now does not get lower then -38C, tho its more up north then were I grew up, its not like back home were I use to walk to school at -48C lol!

snippet.textDisplay:
Hydrogen on the roads, I don't see it. Battery production is improving to the point we should have extremely rapid charging, plus well over 500 km of range within 10 years, and much lower amounts of contentious minerals required than in petrol refining. Plus, with smart meters and integration into the grid, the infrastructure already mostly in place will improve drastically, reducing the need for peak plants.

Hydrogen, combined with solar, wind and batteries can probably power ships and slower airplanes in a couple of decades. And we definitely should switch to something better there. Ships in international waters use fuel of such low quality that some aircraft pilots call in to signal potential fires on ships, as the burnt fuel produces so much soot and pollution that it looks as though the ships themselves are ablaze.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hydrogen on the roads, I don't see it. Battery production is improving to the point we should have extremely rapid charging, plus well over 500 km of range within 10 years, and much lower amounts of contentious minerals required than in petrol refining. Plus, with smart meters and integration into the grid, the infrastructure already mostly in place will improve drastically, reducing the need for peak plants.

Hydrogen, combined with solar, wind and batteries can probably power ships and slower airplanes in a couple of decades. And we definitely should switch to something better there. Ships in international waters use fuel of such low quality that some aircraft pilots call in to signal potential fires on ships, as the burnt fuel produces so much soot and pollution that it looks as though the ships themselves are ablaze.

snippet.textDisplay: Absolutely correct James; one of them could be the future. The other one is only cleverly named for the future, but is in reality just some idiotic attempt to make hydrogen fuel cells relevant and actually viable as a solution. They aren't really either of those things. Battery-only electrics like the Tesla have equal or superior range and power, can be recharged anywhere that electricity is available, and long-term costs can be reduced further by solar charging.
snippet.textOriginal: Absolutely correct James; one of them could be the future. The other one is only cleverly named for the future, but is in reality just some idiotic attempt to make hydrogen fuel cells relevant and actually viable as a solution. They aren't really either of those things. Battery-only electrics like the Tesla have equal or superior range and power, can be recharged anywhere that electricity is available, and long-term costs can be reduced further by solar charging.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hydrogen is inefficient. Yes, but in the future we will have an abundance of clean energy... No, not in the near future anyway.

He said one good thing. With a Bev you can charge at home most of the time, you don't need to go to fuel stationens. That's very much so owning an ev. He also says it takes a long time doing on long trips with av ev. The only thing is, it doesn't. I'm driving a 5h 10 min drive on Thursday, including charging it takes 5h 30 min. That's really not a problem. At the same time I'm saving 50 eur, that's 150 eur per hour ;).

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you Mr May for making a point for hydrogen cars. I do believe this is the future. Yes they are expensive to run and very ugly at the moment but with time this will change. I would have no problem paying more than diesel knowing that my car does not pollute. Battery cars pollute when the batteries need replacing. A hydrogen car will not need any parts replacing not even after 50 years.

snippet.textDisplay:
Some good points... I really think we should have both hydrogen and battery powered EV's. I really feel as if hydrogen has been c*ck blocked and if the same amount of research and effort had gone into it as had batteries, we'd have both right now and both would be readily available and we'd have less carbon emissions, since that is what all the greenies are really supposedly worried about.


In the US, I really feel that if hydrogen and battery EV's were available at reasonable prices eventually the market would settle to about a 60/25/15 split between hydrogen, battery, and ICE vehicles and our air would be cleaner.


I'm really curious as to why we don't have HEV semi tractor trailers... how would the range and pulling power compare to the common diesel rigs we have everywhere?

snippet.textDisplay:
Since one if the main reasons to use an EV is clean energy, consider that part of that cleanliness is replacing fossil fuel.
So why use 75% more if it when that could be used to replace fossil fuel somewhere else, like powering homes?
Rule #1 for the next decade.
Use baseload power efficiently in all applications.

Mazda and Honda not far behind. No ev plans what so ever. Many countries are already banning petrol powered cars and trucks by certain dates. Many of those dates are not far away.
